item.title: Papal Responses to Sexual Abuse in the Church
item.description: A tribunal set up by Pope Francis is the Vatican’s first mechanism to discipline negligent Roman Catholic bishops, rather than abusive priests.
item.dc:creator: KARIN ROBERTS

item.title: Marguerite Patten, Acclaimed British Food Writer and Home Economist, Dies at 99
item.description: Starting out during the rationing years of the 1940s and 1950s, Ms. Patten, who wrote more than 170 books, was one of Britain’s first television chefs.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM GRIMES
item.media:description: During World War II, Marguerite Patten became known as the queen of ration-book cuisine for her simple, satisfying creations.

item.title: World Briefing: Syria: An American Dies in a Battle
item.description: The American, Keith Broomfield of Massachusetts, died June 3 in a battle in a Syrian village near the border town of Kobani.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Lebanon: U.S. Puts 3 Lebanese on Blacklist Over Hezbollah Links
item.description: The Treasury Department froze any assets the Lebanese might have under United States jurisdiction and prohibited Americans from doing business with them.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: West Bank: Palestinian Is Killed
item.description: Israeli forces killed a member of the Palestinian Islamist group Hamas during a raid in the occupied West Bank on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Sudan: Attacks Uproot Thousands
item.description: Increasing attacks on civilians in the Darfur region have forced tens of thousands of people to flee their homes this year.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Poland: Officials Quit Over Scandal
item.description: Four government ministers and the speaker of the Parliament speaker tendered their resignations on Wednesday amid a revived 2014 scandal over secret recordings.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: News Analysis: Trainers Intended as Lift, but Quick Iraq Turnaround Is Unlikely
item.description: President Obama’s plan does not call for American troops to accompany Iraqi fighters onto the battlefield to call in airstrikes or advise them on combat operations.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: United States Army trainers and Iraqi recruits in April. President Obama plans an additional 450 trainers and other personnel.

item.title: Pope Creates Tribunal for Bishop Negligence in Child Sexual Abuse Cases
item.description: Roman Catholic bishops accused of covering up or failing to prevent the sexual abuse of children by priests will be subject to judgment and discipline by the tribunal.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO and LAURIE GOODSTEIN
item.media:description: Bishops greeted Pope Francis at the end of his Wednesday general audience in Saint Peter's Square at Vatican City.

item.title: Hackers May Have Obtained Names of Chinese With Ties to U.S. Government
item.description: Lost data from the Office of Personnel Management may have included the names of Chinese who could now suffer retaliation.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER and JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.media:description: The Office of Personnel Management building in Washington. The names of Chinese relatives, friends and frequent associates of American diplomats and other government officials may be in the hands of Chinese hackers.

item.title: Sorrow Revisits Town as Students Killed in Germanwings Crash Are Brought Home
item.description: The 16 high school students and two teachers from Haltern am See, Germany, were among the first 44 of the 150 victims of the crash in the French Alps to be repatriated
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: A Lufthansa cargo plane, at top, carrying remains of German victims of the Germanwings plane crash landed at the Düsseldorf Airport on Tuesday.

item.title: Evan Solomon, CBC Host, Fired Over Role in Art Deals
item.description: Evan Solomon, a political TV and radio host, was said to have made 300,000 Canadian dollars from introducing wealthy guests of his shows to an art collector.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN
item.media:description: Canada’s public broadcaster fired Evan Solomon, left, a political program host, after a media report said he received commissions from art sales to guests on the program.

item.title: Libya Groups Vow to Crush Unit of ISIS
item.description: A coalition of Islamist militias has vowed to eliminate a local unit of the Islamic State, testing its strength and emphasizing the deep divisions among the country’s Islamist forces.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: South Korean Hamlet, Under MERS Quarantine, Symbolizes Weaknesses in System
item.description: “You can’t leave here unless you have wings,” said a Buddhist monk who runs a temple in the village, Jangdeok, where all residents are quarantined.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Medical staff at Seoul Medical Center. South Korea has nine confirmed MERS deaths.

item.title: Ludvik Vaculik, Influential Czech Writer and Dissident, Dies at 88
item.description: Mr. Vaculik not only wrote some great books, one expert said, but he also “influenced events and spearheaded political changes” in Czechoslovakia, especially the “Prague Spring” of 1968.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Militants Hit Karnak Temple, in 2nd Recent Attack on Egyptian Tourist Sites
item.description: The explosion in Luxor came about a week after gunmen shot and killed two tourism police officers near the pyramids of Giza, raising fears that militants want to hurt the tourism sector.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: After Days of Losses, the Market Turns Around
item.description: Potential advances in negotiations over Greece’s debts prompted all 30 stocks in the Dow Jones industrial average to end in the green on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Copa América Set to Begin Under a Cloud
item.description: The recent arrests of FIFA officials and other businessmen have shed unflattering light on the soccer event, especially since some charges involved schemes involving the Copa.
item.dc:creator: DAVID WALDSTEIN
item.media:description: A street market in Santiago, Chile, offered caps and scarves of the countries playing in the Copa América soccer tournament, which begins on Thursday.

item.title: Malaysia Detains 4 Westerners Accused of Taking Nude Photos on Mountain
item.description: Some local officials have been quoted as suspecting a connection between the trekkers’ behavior and an earthquake weeks later that killed 18 people.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Mount Kinabalu, Malaysia’s highest peak, on Saturday, a day after an earthquake left 18 people dead.

item.title: Pope Urges Putin to Make a ‘Great Effort’ to Resolve the Crisis in Ukraine
item.description: The Russian president, who enjoys better relations with Italy than with other European countries, also met with the pope.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia meets with Pope Francis at the Vatican on Wednesday during his visit to Rome.
